podcast_script:
[INTRO MUSIC FADES IN]

Hey everyone, welcome to MikeCast ‚Äî your daily news briefing. It's February 24, 2026, and I've got a packed show for you today. Let's dive right in.


--- AI & TECH ---

Starting with AI & Tech.

The big story here is: Binance Employees Find $1.7 Billion in Crypto Was Sent to Iranian Entities. Binance pledged to crack down on crime. But internal investigators at the world‚Äôs largest crypto exchange continued to find evidence of potential legal violations on the platform.

Also worth noting: The Lesson of A.I. Literacy Class: Don‚Äôt Let the Chatbot Think for You. Teachers say they want to equip high school students to drive artificial intelligence, rather than be mere passengers steered by chatbots.

Also worth noting: Anthropic Accuses 3 Chinese Companies of Harvesting Its Data. The San Francisco start-up claimed that DeepSeek, Moonshot and MiniMax used approximately 24,000 fraudulent accounts to train their own chatbots.

Also worth noting: Backed by Anthropic, a Super PAC Group Begins an Ad Blitz in Support of A.I. Regulation. The ads by Public First Action, which started airing on Monday, are part of an escalating political war over artificial intelligence before the midterm elections.


--- BUSINESS & MARKETS ---

Starting with Business & Markets.

The big story here is: Saks Owner Says He Saved Department Stores. Never Mind the Bankruptcy.. Richard Baker wanted to create a retail empire when he combined Saks Fifth Avenue and Neiman Marcus. About a year later, it filed for bankruptcy.

Also worth noting: More Than Half a Million Customers Have Lost Power on East Coast. The outages were mostly caused by problems with local power lines, and coastal Massachusetts was particularly hard hit.

Also worth noting: Tariff Turmoil Returns to Global Markets. Businesses and U.S. trade partners are again grappling with the uncertainty of President Trump‚Äôs trade war, even as he imposes new levies.

Also worth noting: Top Fed Official Sees Little Effect on Rate Outlook From Supreme Court‚Äôs Tariff Ruling. Christopher J. Waller, a Federal Reserve governor, said he would support a pause in rate cuts in March if the labor market continued to show signs of stabilizing.
